description: A tendency among mainly New York painters committed to an expressive art of profound emotion and universal themes, Abstract Expressionism embraces the spacial breakthroughs of Jackson Pollock, Color Field painting of Mark Rothko, as well as the gestural abstraction of Willem de Kooning.
artists: Jackson Pollock, Willem de Kooning, Mark Rothko, Clyfford Still
artworks: "Autumn Rhythm (Number 30)", "Excavation", "No. 6 (Violet, Green, Red)","1957-D-No. 1"

description: Not relying on the usual facets of photography - focus, composition, and theme - abstract photography uses color, shade and form as its subject matter, much the way abstract painters do.
artists: Paul Strand, Christian Schad, Man Ray, Alfred Stieglitz
artworks: "Porch Shadows", "Schadograph", "Rayograph", "Equivalent"

description: Action Painting was a term coined by art critic Harold Rosenberg to refer to the gestural and somewhat existential mode of Abstract Expressionism, often characterized by drips, flung paint, and rapid, spontaneous strokes by the artist. In this view the painting is a record of the artist's activities over time.
artists: Jackson Pollock, Franz Kline, Willem de Kooning, Joan Mitchell
artworks: "Autumn Rhythm (Number 30)", "Chief", "Woman III", "Untitled (1954)"

description: The Aesthetic Movement emerged first in Britain by a rejection of previous styles in both the fine and decorative arts, its adherents were committed to the pursuit of beauty and the doctrine of 'art for art's sake'. Believing that art had declined in an era of utility and rationalism, they claimed that art deserved to be judged on its own terms alone.
artists: James Whistler, Dante Gabriel Rossetti, Lord Frederic Leighton
artworks: "Nocturne: Blue and Gold - Old Battersea Bridge", "La Ghirlandata", "The Bath of Psyche"

description: American Impressionism was a painting style borrowed from French Impressionism, practiced by artists in the US and abroad from the late-nineteenth century to the early twentieth century.
artists: Mary Cassatt, John Singer Sargent, Childe Hassam
artworks: "Woman Sitting with a Child in Her Arms", "Paul Helleu Sketching with his Wife", "Surf, Isles of Shoals"

description: Regionalism emerged in 1930s as an alternative to the abstract and avant-garde veins of modern art. Executed in a realist style, it often depicted scenes of everyday rural life, and frequently featured allegories about land, labor, and American history.
artists: John Steuart Curry, Grant Wood, Thomas Hart Benton
artworks: "Baptism in Kansas", "American Gothic", "City Activities with Subway"

description: Art Brut, or in French "raw/rough art," was a label made by French artist Jean Dubuffet to describe art that was created by self-taught, naïve artists. Also known as Outsider Artists, these creators were often categorized as mentally unbalanced, and their aesthetics were mostly outside the common art world.
artists: Adolf Wölfli, Ferdinand Cheval, Séraphine Louis
artworks: "Mental Asylum Band-Copse", "La Palais Idéal", "The Tree of Life"

description: Art Deco was an eclectic style that flourished in the 1920s and '30s and influenced art, architecture and design. It blended a love of modernity - expressed through geometric shapes and streamlined forms - with references to the classical past and to exotic locations.
artists: Réne Lalique, Emile-Jacques Ruhlmann, A.M. Cassandre
artworks: "Victoire", "État Cabinet", "Pivolo Aperitif Aux Vins De France"

description: Responding to the atrocities and traumas of World War II, the artists associated with Art Informel embraced abstraction and gestural techniques.
artists: Jean Fautrier, Wols, Maria Helena Vieira da Silva
artworks: "La Juive", "It's All Over", "The Corridor"

description: Art Nouveau was a movement that swept through the decorative arts and architecture in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Artists drew inspiration from both organic and geometric forms, evolving elegant designs that united flowing, natural forms with more angular contours.
artists: Gustav Klimt, Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec, Aubrey Beardsley
artworks: "The Kiss", "La Goulue at the Moulin Rouge", "The Peacock Skirt"

description: Arte Povera is a style of modern art. The term was introduced in Italy during a period of upheaval at the end of the 1960s. The term centered on a group of Italian artists who attacked established institutions with art made from unconventional materials. They often used found objects in their works.
artists: Piero Manzoni, Luciano Fabro
artworks: "Artist's Sh*t (no. 4)", "Floor Tautology"

description: The Arts and Crafts Movement was an international design movement that originated in Great Britain and had a strong following in the US. It advocated truth to materials and traditional craftsmanship using simple forms and often medieval, romantic or folk styles of decoration. It also proposed economic and social reform and has been seen as essentially anti-industrial.
artists: Philip Webb, William Morris, Morris & Co.
artworks: "Red House", "Geoffrey Chaucer's Canterbury Tales", "Tulip and Rose"

description: The Ashcan Realist artists painted in a more naturalistic and socially-engaged manner than their early American avant-garde peers.
artists: Robert Henri, William Glackens, George Luks
artworks: "Portrait of Willie Gee", "At Mouquin's", "Hester Street"

description: Named after the village of Barbizon, France where the artists gathered, the group of outdoor, Naturalist painters included Jean-Baptiste Camille Corot, Theodore Rousseau, and Jean-François Millet.
artists: Jean-Baptiste-Camille Corot, Jules Dupré, Jean-Baptiste Gustave Le Gray
artworks: "Fontainebleau: Oak Trees at Bas-Bréau", "Oak Trees and Pond", "The Beech Tree"

description: Baroque art and architecture emerged in late sixteenth-century Europe after the Renaissance, and lasted into the eighteenth century. In contrast to the clarity and order of earlier art, it stressed theatrical atmosphere, dynamic flourishes, and myriad colors and textures.
artists:
Caravaggio, 
Peter Paul Rubens, 
Artemisia Gentileschi, 
Rembrandt van Rijn
artworks:
"The Calling of St Matthew", 
"Le debarquement de Marie de Médicis au port de Marseille le 3 November", 
"Judith and Holofernes", 
"The Night Watch"

description: Bauhaus is a style and movement associated with the Bauhaus school, an extremely influential art and design school in Weimar Germany that emphasized the functionality and efficiency of design alongside its material properties. Prominent teachers include Josef Albers, Walter Gropius, Wassily Kandinsky, Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, and Paul Klee.
artists: Paul Klee, Wassily Kandinsky, Marcel Breuer
artworks: "Red Balloon", "Yellow-Red-Blue", "Club Chair (Model B3)"

description: The Bay Area Figurative Movement emerged in the 1950s and 60s around the San Francisco Bay. Heavily influenced by the color fields and painterly brushwork of Abstract Expressionism, they later moved away from abstraction in a more figurative direction.
artists: David Park, Elmer Bischoff, Manuel Neri
artworks: "Kids on Bikes", "Orange Sweater", "Untitled (Standing Figure)"

description: Biomorphism was genre of twentieth-century art with close ties to Surrealism. The term referred to styles of painting and sculpture that assumed an organic appearance or form, and contained characteristics reminiscent of nature.
artists: Joan Miró, Yves Tanguy, Hans Arp
artworks: "Harlequin's Carnival", "Mama, Papa is Wounded!", "Cloud Shepherd"

description: Black Mountain College was an experimental school founded in the middle of the twentieth century on the principles of balancing academics, arts, and manual labor within a democratic, communal society and influnced many important artists.
artists: Anni Albers, Josef Albers, Jacob Lawrence
artworks: "Monte Albán", "Leaf Study IX", "Watchmaker"

description: The artists of the Bloomsbury Group were innovative British painters, designers, and art critics Bell, Grant, Wood+ breathed fresh life into the stuffy 1900's art scene.
artists: Roger Fry, Wyndham Lewis, Frederick Etchells
artworks: "River With Poplars", "Candleshade Designs For The Omega Workshops", "The Big Girl"

description: Many Performance artists used their bodies as the subjects, and the objects of their art and thereby expressed their distinctive views in the newly liberated social, political, and sexual climate of the 1960s. From different actions involving the body, to acts of physical endurance, tattoos, and even extreme forms of bodily mutilation are all included in the loose movement of Body art.
artists: Yves Klein, Yayoi Kusama, VALIE EXPORT
artworks: "Anthropométrie sans titre", "Sex Obsession Food Obsession Macaroni Infinity Nets & Kusama", "Body, Sign, Action"

description: The Pop art movement emerged in Britain before becoming enourmously popular in the United States. Early practitioners such as Eduardo Paolozzi and Richard Hamilton set the scene for the achievement of legends such as Warhol and Lichtenstein.
artists: Eduardo Paolozzi, Richard Hamilton, Peter Blake
artworks: "I was a rich man's plaything", "Just what is it that makes today's homes so different, so appealing?", "On the Balcony"

description: The Capital Realists shared a critical stance toward the invasion of American consumerism into West Germany.
artists: Gerhard Richter, Sigmar Polke, Wolf Vostell
artworks: "Stag (Hirsch)", "Girlfriends", "Starfighter I"

description: CoBrA was an avant-garde art collective spanned the cities of Copenhagen, Brussels, and Amsterdam, focused on elements of spontaneity, experimentation, primitivism, and fantasy
artists: Karel Appel, Constant Anton Nieuwenhuys, Carl-Henning Pedersen
artworks: "Questioning Children", "After Us, Liberty", "The Red Ship"

description: A tendency within Abstract Expressionism, distinct from gestural abstraction, color field painting is characterized by large fields of color and an absence of any figurative motifs, and often expresses a yearning for transcendence and the infinite.
artists: Clyfford Still, Mark Rothko, Helen Frankenthaler
artworks: "1957-D-No. 1", "No. 2, Green, Red and Blue", "Mountains and Sea"

description: The practice of Conceptual art became popular after the 1960s and presented people with an idea about art, which was more significant than the completion of a tangible and traditional work of 'art'. The aim was to create a concept that obliged people to consider the nature of art itself, and decide for themselves whether what was present was a work of art.
artists: Robert Rauschenberg, Joseph Kosuth, Walter de Maria
artworks: "Erased de Kooning Drawing", "One and Three Chairs", "Vertical Earth Kilometer"

description: Concrete artists based their compositions on mathematical and scientific formulas, rejecting any semblance of naturalistic subject matter.
artists: Piet Mondrian, Max Bill, Richard Paul Lohse
artworks: "Composition with Red, Blue, and Yellow", "Endless Ribbon", "Squares Formed by Color Groups"

description: Concrete poetry is a type of poetry or language-based art in which the way words and letters are visually presented is as important as what they mean.
artists: Eugen Gomringer, Augusto de Campos, Décio Pignatari
artworks: "Silencio", "Sem Um Numero", "Bebe Coca Cola"

description: Contructivism was a movement that emerged in Revolutionary Russia among such artists as Vladimir Tatlin, Aleksander Rodchenko, Antoine Pevsner, and Naum Gabo. Celebrating 'art as machine,' it emphasized space, construction, and industrial materials.
artists: Vladimir Tatlin, Alexander Rodchenko, Lyubov Popova
artworks: "Corner Counter-Relief", "Pure Red Color, Pure Yellow Color, Pure Blue Color", "Textile Design"

description: Contemporary Realism emerged in direct defiance to the immense popularity of New York's, postwar Abstract Expressionism. The loose group focused on a return to a straightforward, figurative representation of life.
artists: Jane Freilicher, Alex Katz, Leland Bell
artworks: "Early New York Evening", "The Black Dress", "Croquet Party"

description: Cubism was first developed by Pablo Picasso and Georges Braque between 1907-1911. Its classic phase has two stages: 'Analytic', in which forms seem to be 'analyzed' and fragmented; and 'Synthetic', in which foreign materials such as newspaper and wood veneer are collaged to the surface of the canvas. The style attracted many adherents, both in Paris and abroad, and it would later influence the Abstract Expressionists, particularly Willem de Kooning.
artists: Pablo Picasso, George Braque, Jean Metzinger
artworks: "Les Demoiselles d'Avignon", "Houses at L'Estaque", "Tea Time"

description: Dada emerged in the early twentieth century as a literary and artistic movement that celebrated random chance, readymade artworks, and outragous performances. Its practitioners, including Hugo Ball, Tristan Tzara, and Marcel Duchamp, scorned bourgeois conventions of high culture, especially the appreciation for artistic intention and skill.
artists: Francis Picabia, Hugo Ball, Hans Arp
artworks: "Ici, C'est Stieglitz", "Reciting the Sound Poem "Karawane"", "Untitled (Squares Arranged according to the Laws of Chance"

description: This ground-breaking practice of photography was inspired by Dada's improvisational practices and the Surrealist's foray into the unconscious, dream, and fantasy realms. Many artists contributed various works that ultimately stretched the possibilities of the medium.
artists: Hannah Höch, Marcel Duchamp, Man Ray
artworks: "Cut with the Kitchen Knife Through the Last Weimar Beer-Belly Cultural Epoch in Germany", "Dust Breeding", "Le Violin d'Ingres"

description: De Stijl was an avant-garde group dedicated to isolating a single visual style that would be appropriate to all aspects of modern life, from art to design to architecture.
artists: Piet Mondrian, Vilmos Huszar, Gerrit Rietveld
artworks: "Composition A", "Mechano-Dancer", "Red and Blue Chair"

description: Der Blaue Reiter (The Blue Rider) was a group of Expressionist painters in Munich, Germany consisting principally of Wassily Kandinsky, Alexej von Jawlensky,Germans Auguste Macke, and Franz Marc. Key interests among them were the aesthetics of primitivism and spiritualism, as well as growing trends in Fauvism and Cubism, which led Kandinsky, chief among the Expressionist artists, to experiment more with abstract art.
artists: Marianne von Werefkin, Wassily Kandinsky, Franz Marc
artworks: "Self-Portrait", "Cover of Der Blaue Reiter Almanach", "The Yellow Cow"

description: Die Brücke (The Bridge) was a group of German Expressionist artists that banded together in Dresden in 1905. The group, which includes artists such as Erich Heckel, Ernst Ludwig Kirchner, and Emil Nolde, had a major impact on the evolution of modern art in the twentieth century and the creation of Expressionism. Die Bruke artists' used bold colors to depicts gritty scene of city life.
artists: Ernst Ludwig Kirchner, Fritz Bleyl, Karl Schmidt-Rottluff
artworks: "Programme", "Poster for the first Die Brücke Exhibition", "Self-Portrait with Monocle"

description: In the digital age, artists would grasp its progressive technologies for their own creative output including television, computers, a/v software, and the internet. Beginning in the 1960s, artists and innovators have expanded art into new, and sometimes virtual, worlds.
artists: Frieder Nake, Kenneth C. Knowlton, Allan Kaprow
artworks: "Hommage à Paul Klee 13/9/65 Nr.2", "Young Nude", "Hello"

description: Documentary photography attempts to portray various realities and is best thought of as an umbrella term that encompasses many styles including Social Documentary, Conservation Photography, Ethnographic Photography, War Photography, and the photo essay.
artists: Jacob Riis, Lewis Hine, August Sander
artworks: "Bandits' Roost, 59 1/2 Mulberry Street", "Addie Card, 12 years. Spinner in North Pormal Cotton Mill", "Three Farmers"

description: The Düsseldorf School refers to a group of photographers who studied at the Kunstakademie Düsseldorf in the 1970s under the tutelage of Bernd and Hilla Becher.
artists: Thomas Ruff, Thomas Struth, Andreas Gursky
artworks: "Portait 1986 (Stoya)", "The Smith Family, Fife", "Salerno"

description: Environmental Art refers to art dealing with ecological issues in the aethetic, formal, the political, the historical, or the social context. First associated with Earth art, the expanding term of Environmental Art also encompasses the scope of the urban landscape.
artists: Betty Beaumont, Andy Goldsworthy, Agnes Denes
artworks: "Ocean Landmark", "Pinfold Cones", "Wheatfield, a Confrontation"

description: Expressionism is a broad term for a host of movements in early twentieth-century Germany, from Die Brücke (1905) and Der Blaue Reiter (1911) to the early Neue Sachlichkeit painters in the 20s and 30s. Many German Expressionists used vivid colors and abstracted forms to create spiritually or psychologically intense works, while others focused on depictions of war, alienation, and the modern city.
artists: Edvard Munch, Wassily Kandinsky, Oskar Kokoschka
artworks: "The Scream", "Der Blaue Reiter", "Hans Tietze and Erica Tietze-Conrat"

description: Fashion Photography is a branch of fine art photography that focuses exclusively on the promotion of high culture.
artists: Edward Steichen, Man Ray, Cecil Beaton
artworks: "Gloria Swanson", "Noire et Blanche", "The Hat Box (White panama hat)"

description: Fauvism was an early twentieth-century art movement founded by Henri Matisse and André Derain. Labeled "les fauves" or "wild beasts" by critic Louis Vauxcelles, the artists favored vibrant colors and winding gestural strokes across the canvas.
artists: Henri Matisse, Maurice de Vlaminck, André Derain
artworks: "Luxe, Calme et Volupte", "The River Seine at Chatou", "Pinède à Cassis (Landscape)"

description: Feminist art emerged in the 1960s and '70s to explore questions of sex, power, the body, and the ways in which gender categories structure how we see and understand the world. Developing at the same time as many new media strategies, feminist art frequently involves text, installation, and performance elements.
artists: Mary Beth Edelson, Judy Chicago, Lynda Benglis
artworks: "Some Living Women Artists/Last Supper", "Womanhouse", "ArtForum Advertisement"

description: Fluxus was an international network of "intermedia" artists of the 1960s who worked in fields ranging from music to performance to the visual arts. Taking their name from the Latin "to flow," Fluxus artists adopted an often anarchic and satirical approach to conventional forms of art, and their ideas paved the way for Conceptual art.
artists: Yoko Ono, Robert Filliou, Ben Vautier
artworks: "Cut Piece", "Optimistic Box #3 - So much the better if you can't play chess (you won't imitate Marcel Duchamp)", "Total Art Matchbox"

description: The painters Raphael Soyer, Isabel Bishop, Reginald Marsh, and others of the members of the Fourteenth Street School depicted New York denizens before and during the Great Depression.
artists: Kenneth Hayes Miller, Edward Laning, Isabel Bishop
artworks: "The Fitting Room", "Breezy Day on the Avenue", "Dante and Virgil in Union Square"

description: Futurism developed in interwar Italy as an ideology that celebrated the speed, movement, machinery, and violence of modern times. Blending realism with collage and Cubist abstraction, its visual components include lines of force and dynamism to indicate objects moving through space.
artists: Umberto Boccioni, Carlo Carrà, Giacomo Balla
artworks: "The City Rises", "Funeral of the Anarchist Galli", "Dynamism of a Dog on a Leash"

description: Group f/64 photographers shared a common photographic style characterized by sharp-focused and carefully framed images. The California group followed and developed the Straight Photography approach of their East Coast peers.
artists: Imogen Cunningham, Edward Weston, Willard Van Dyke
artworks: "Magnolia Blossom", "[Nude]", "Bone and Sky"

description: The Gutai was a Japanese artistic movement that was founded by Jiro Yoshihara in 1954. The group was preoccupied with beauty that is born from things that are damaged or decayed. Members believed the destructive process revealed the inner life of materials and objects.
artists: Kazuo Shiraga, Saburõ Murakami, Jirõ Yoshihara
artworks: “Challenge To The Mud”, “Laceration of Paper”, “Please Draw Freely”

description: The term "happening" was coined by artist Allan Kaprow in 1957 to decribe an art event, often staged or pre-scripted, that requires active participation from an audience to come to full fruition.
artists: Robert Whitman, Allan Kaprow, Robert Watts
artworks: "American Moon", "Yard", "Stamp Vendor"

description: Hard-edge painting, emerging in the 1950s and 60s, departs from the gesture and scrawl of Abstract Expressionism to favor blocks of color with well-defined edges.
artists: Karl Benjamin, Frederick Hammersley, Lorser Feitelson
artworks: “Black Pillars (1957)”, “Opposing #15”, “Dichotomic Organization”

description: The Harlem Renaissance was the name given to the cultural, social, and artistic explosion that took place in Harlem between the end of World War I and the middle of the 1930s.
artists: Meta Vaux Warrick Fuller, Augusta Savage, James Van Der Zee
artworks: "Ethiopia Awakening", "Gamin", "Couple in Raccoon Coats"

description: The Hudson River School was a nineteenth century American art movement that celebrated the wilderness and great outdoors. The Hudson River School artists were influenced by the Romantics, using dramatic scenes of nature to express the American ideals of their time: discovery and exploration.
artists: Thomas Cole, Asher B. Durand, George Inness
artworks: "The Falls of Kaaterskill", "Kindred Spirits", "The Lackawanna Valley"

description: Beginning in the 1960s, artists of color, LGBTQ+ artists, and women have used their art to stage and display experiences of identity and community.
artists: Judy Chicago, Cindy Sherman, James Luna
artworks: "Dinner Party", "Untitled Film Still #35", "Artifact Piece"

description: Impressionism emerged in the mid-nineteent century in opposition to the finished style of academic painting. It often depicted scenes of daily life, and used painterly strokes and shifting color areas to capture the effects of light and atmosphere.
artists: Édouard Manet, Alfred Sisley, Berthe Morisot
artworks: "Le déjeuner sur l'herbe", "Fog, Voisins", "In a Park"

description: Installation art is a genre of contemporary art-making in which two- and three-dimensional materials are used to transform a particular site into an immersive space for the visitor. Installations may include sculptural, found, sound-based, and performance elements, and can be permanent or ephemeral.
artists: Marcel Duchamp, Judy Chicago, Tracy Emin
artworks: "Étant donnés", "The Dinner Party", "My Bed"

description: Institutional Critique is the practice of systematic inquiry into the workings of art institutions and their connections to the development of art. Institutional Critique focuses on the relationships between the viewer, language, process, the consumption of art.
artists: Daniel Buren, Marcel Broodthaers, Hans Haacke
artworks: "Affichages Sauvages", "Musée d'Art Moderne", "MoMA Poll"

description: The International Style was a style of modern architecture that emerged in the 1920s and '30s. It emphasized balance, the importance of function, and clean lines devoid of ornamentation. Glass and steel buildings, with less emphasis on conrete, is the most common and pure realization of structures in this style.
artists: Walter Gropius, Le Corbusier, Lilly Reich
artworks: "Bauhaus, Dessau, Germany", "Villa Savoye, Poissy-sur-Seine, France", "German Pavillion, Barcelona, Spain"

description: Europe experienced a harsh interwar period after the chaos and aftermath of World War I, and with the onset of the Great Depression. Meanwhile artists focused on the so-called "return to order" (rappel a l'ordre), a renewal of depictions of Greek and Roman topics and imagery.
artists: Pablo Picasso, Giorgio de Chirico, Aristide Maillol
artworks: "Mother and Child", "Self Portait", "Mediterranean"

description: Japonism describes the influence of Japanese art, especially woodblock prints, on French artists in the second half of the nineteenth century. Many Post-Impressionists were influenced by the flat blocks of color, the emphasis on design, and the everyday subject matter.
artists: Édouard Manet, Edward William Godwin, James Whistler
artworks: "Portrait of Émile Zola", "Sideboard", "Harmony in Blue and Gold: The Peacock Room"

description: Rising to prominence in Germany in the late nineteenth century, Jugendstil, which means "youth style" in German, influenced the visual arts (particularly graphic design and typography), decorative arts, and architecture.
artists: Georg Hulbe, Hans Christiansen, Peter Behrens
artworks: "Leather Screen", "Andromeda", "Der Kuss"

description: Kinetic art is usually a sculptural construction comprised of moving components, powered by wind, a motor or the viewers themselves. Its kinesis is what gives the artwork its overall effect, hence the name. The first artwork generally credited as Kinetic Art was Marcel Duchamp's Bicycle Wheel (1913). Some of the medium's most famous practitioners include Alexander Calder, Naum Gabo and Jean Tingeuly.
artists: Marcel Duchamp, Naum Gabo, László Moholy-Nagy
artworks: "Bicycle Wheel", "Kinetic Construction (Standing Wave)", "Light Prop for an Electric Stage (Light Space Modulator)"

description: Les Nabis were a group of Post-Impressionist artists in 1890s Paris including Maurice Denis, Pierre Bonnard, and Édouard Vuillard. They combined Impressionist brushstrokes with vivid colors, an at-times mystical or symbolic subject matter, and an interest in patterned and repeating backgrounds.
artists: Paul Sérusier, Paul Ranson, Félix Vallotton
artworks: "The Talisman, the River Aven at the Bois d'Amour", "Nabi Landscape", "L'Indolence (Laziness)"

description: Light and Space is an art movement founded in the 1960s that was connected to several different contemporary movements including minimalism, op-art, and geometric abstraction. The California-based movement focused on creating works related to light, volume, and scale through installations.
artists: Robert Irwin, John McCracken, Helen Pashgian
artworks: "Untitled (1966-1967)", "The Absolutely Naked Fragrance", "Untitled (1969)"

description: Luminism refers to a mid-nineteenth-century American school of painting, in which artists emphasized the effects of light and shadow in expansive landscapes. Luminism is related to French Impressionism given their respective emphases on light, but differs in that the American artists hid their brushstrokes and paid closer attention to glowing scenes of nature.
artists: George Harvey, William Sidney Mount, George Caleb Bingham
artworks: "Pittsford on the Erie Canal", "Eel Spearing at Setauket", "Fur Traders Descending the Missouri"

description: Magic Realist art plays off subtle strangeness, merges present and past, invents strange objects, and juxtaposes unlike things.
artists: Frida Kahlo, George Tooker, Andrew Wyeth
artworks: "Beach of Dangast with Flying Boat", "Late Visitors to Pompeii", "Into the World Where There Came a Soul Called Ida"

description: Metaphysical Painting was developed in 1917 by Giorgio de Chirico and Carlo Carra. The works created a sense of mystery through the use of dreamlike imagery; objects often appeared in strange, unfamiliar contexts. A reaction against Cubism and Futurism, the movement paved the way for Surrealism.
artists: Giorgio de Chirico, Giorgio Morandi
artworks: "The Enigma of an Autumn Afternoon", "The Song of Love"

description: Mexican Muralism was a vibrant movement whose artists created large-scale works, executed in Mexico and the US. Relying on a mixture of Mexican heritage and classical Italian styles, murals were frequently done in a figurative, allegorical style and dealt with political, social, and radical themes.
artists: Diego Rivera, José Clemente Orozco, David Alfaro Siqueiros
artworks: "The Creation", "Los Dazantes de Chalma", "The Banquet of the Rich"

description: Minimalism emerged in the 1960s in response to the gestural and autographic excesses of Abstract Expressionism. Its early practitioners constructed huge geometric objects, serial structures, and simplified gridded planes.
artists: Carl Andre, Dan Flavin, Donald Judd
artworks: "Die Fahne Hoch!", "Die", "Lever"

description: Modern photography refers to a range of approaches from Straight Photography, New Vision photography, Dada and Surrealist photography, and later abstract tendencies.
artists: Alfred Stieglitz, Paul Strand, Tina Modotti
artworks: "The Steerage", "Blind", "Workers Parade"

description: Naturalism is a movement within painting where the human subject is depicted in natural habitats and social milieus, with an emphasis on visual accuracy.
artists: John Constable, Theodore Rousseau, Thomas Cole
artworks: "The Hay Wain", "Sunrise in the Catskills", "View of the Forest of Fontainebleau"

description: Looking back to the arts of Greece and Rome for ideal models and forms, Neoclassicism was a major art period that set standard and redefined painting, sculpture, and architecture.
artists: Benjamin West, Antonio Canova, Jean-Antoine Houdon
artworks: "Death of General Wolfe", "Psyche Revived by Cupid's Kiss", "Voltaire"

description: Neo-Dada refers to works of art from the 1950s that employ popular imagery and modern materials, often resulting in a subtle commentary on the contemporary world. Neo-Dada is both a continuation of the earlier Dada movement and an important precursor to Pop art. Some important Neo-Dada artists include Robert Rauschenberg, Jasper Johns, Robert Morris and Allan Kaprow.
artists: Jasper Johns, John Cage, Allan Kaprow
artworks: "Theater Piece No. 1", "Flag", "Suite for Five"

description: Neo-Expressionism began as a movement in German art in the early 1960s with the emergence of Georg Baselitz. It gained momentum, and drew in painters from Germany and the United States - often bringing artists back to painting as a serious and contemporary medium for artistic exploration.
artists: George Baselitz, Phillip Guston, Eric Fischl
artworks: "Adieu", "Café Deutschland I", "Athanor"

description: Commonly referred to as Neo-Geo, Neo-Geometric Conceptualism is an art movement formed in the early 1980s whose members sought to criticize the mechanization and commercialism of their contemporary society through the use of geometric forms and abstraction.
artists: Jeff Koons, Sherrie Levine
artworks: "Red Cell with Conduit", "The Arrangement of Things", "Three Ball Total Equilibrium Tank"

description: Neo-Impressionism was founded by Georges Seurat in the 1880s. It brought a new and quasi-scientific approach to the Impressionists' interests in light and color, along with new approaches to the application of paint, sometimes in dots and dashes. Its followers were drawn to modern urban scenes as well as landscapes and seascapes.
artists: Georges Seurat, Camille Pissaro, Vincent Van Gogh
artworks: "A Sunday Afternoon on La Grande Jatte", "La Dame à la Robe Blanche", "La Récolte des Foins, Éragny"

description: Neo-Plasticism was the guiding philosophy behind the art of Dutch painter Piet Mondrian and many of his peers in the De Stijl circle. Articulated by Mondrian in 1917-18, the approach stipulates the strict use of only horizontal and vertical lines and the primary colors red, yellow, and blue.
artists: Piet Mondrian, Theo van Doesburg
artworks: "Composition with Color Planes 5", "Composition", "Composition With Grid VI"

description: New Objectivity, or Neue Sachlichkeit, was a style of German art that emerged in the 1920s in reaction to post World War I trauma and difficulties. Artists such as Otto Dix were savagely satirical and critical of society, while others evolved a cool and classical style that echoes other European art movements at this time.
artists: Rudolf Schlichter, Max Beckmann
artworks: "The Night", "Tingel-Tangel", "Self-Portait with a Cigarette"

description: Nihonga artists preserved the heritage of classical Japanese painting while reinvigorating it for modern, global exposure and artistic influence.
artists: Kanō Hōgai, Hashimoto Gahō, Shunsō Hishida
artworks: "Hibo Kannon", "Dragon Against Tiger", "Ochiba (Fallen Leaves)"

description: Nouveau Réalisme (New Realism) expanded the materials and ideas of art in a Europe that was recovering from horrible war and a new forms of cultural and commercial consumption.
artists: Arman, Christo, Yves Klein
artworks: "Monochrome Blue", "Shooting Picture", "Baluba"

description: Op art, short for Optical art, is a style of abstraction that relies on geometric shapes, lines, and color juxtapositions to create optical illusions for the viewer. Gaining popularity in the 1960s, such art often features patterns, grids, and effects like curving or diminishing objects.
artists: Victor Vasarely, Bridget Riley, Frank Stella
artworks: "Structural Constellation", "Blaze", "Duo- 2"

description: Orientalism is the term used by scholars to describe Westerners fascination with the Middle East, Asia, and North Africa in the nineteenth century. This fascination inspired a new wave of art (including painting and literature) that featured scenes from these societies, often dramatized and highly eroticized.
artists: Jean-Auguste-Dominique Ingres, Eugène Delacroix, Théodore Chassériau
artworks: "Grande Odalisque", "Women of Algiers in their Apartment", "Scene in the Jewish Quarter of Constantine"

description: Orphism was a French art movement that brought together contemporary theories of philosophy and color there were pioneered mainly by Robert and Sonia Delaunays.
artists: Robert Delaunay, Sonia Delaunay, Franz Marc
artworks: "The City of Paris", "Couverture de Berceau", "The Rhythm (Adam and Eve)"

description: The Russian "Itinerants" or "Wanderers" were a group of painters specializing in archetypal Russian views such as pine forests, wheat fields, and water meadows.
artists: Ilya Repin, Alexei Savrasov, Fyodor Vasilyev
artworks: "Barge Haulers on the Volga", "The Rooks Have Come Back", "Wet Meadow"

description: Performance art is a modern form of art that emphasizes the experiential and the relationship between performer and audience. It developed in the 1960s with such artists as Yves Klein, Joseph Beuys, Marina Abramovic and Allan Kaprow. Not to be confused with the performing arts (dance, theater and music), Performance art is closely related to Conceptual art, in which any inherent meaning is in the eye of the beholder.
artists: Zhang Huan, Yoko Ono, Yves Klein
artworks: "The Anthropometries of the Blue Period", "Cut Piece", "Shoot"

description: Photojournalism hit its stride as an approach to photography in the middle of the twentieth century with the commitment to impartiality in news and story-telling as was exemplified by Henri Cartier-Bresson, Dorothea Lange, and Robert Capa.
artists: Henri Cartier-Bresson, Weegee, Josef Koudelka
artworks: "The Crawlers", "A Harvest of Death, Gettysburg, Pennsylvania, July 4, 1863", "Valley of the Shadow of Death, April 23, 1855"

description: Photorealism is a style of painting that was developed by such artists as Chuck Close, Audrey Flack and Richard Estes. Photorealists often utilize painting techniques to mimic the effects of photography and thus blur the line that have typically divided the two mediums.
artists: Chuck Close, Richard Estes, Ralph Goings
artworks: "Self-Portait (1967-68)", "McDonalds Pickup", "Supreme Hardware Store"

description: The dominant movement in early photography, Pictorialism refers to manipulated images that include lack of sharp focus, using colors other than black and white, and changes on the surface of the work.
artists: Henry Peach Robinson, Julia Margaret Cameron, George Davison
artworks: "Fading Away", "The Mountain Nymph Sweet Library", "The Onion Field, Mersea Island, Essex"

description: Pop art was a movement that developed in 1950s America in response to Abstract Expressionism's emphasis on formal qualities and inner expression. Artists like Jasper Johns, Robert Rauschenberg, Andy Warhol, and Roy Lichtenstein tried to subvert the artist's hand through techniques like serial printing, everyday materials, and pop culture imagery.
artists: Eduardo Paolozzi, Richard Hamilton, James Rosenquist
artworks: "I was a rich man's plaything", "Just what is it that makes today's homes so different, so appealing?", "President Elect"

description: Post-Impressioism refers to a host of artists and styles that emerged after Impressionism in the late nineteenth century. Although diverse in style, they tend to share an emphasis on intense, sometimes arbitrary, colors, expressive forms, and painterly brushstrokes.
artists: Paul Cézanne, Vincent Van Gogh, Paul Gaugin
artworks: "Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte", "Vision After the Sermon", "Self-Portait with Waroquy"

description: Post-minimalism refers to works that share the "pure" qualities of older Minimalist works but go beyond the formalist or linear aesthetics. Some of the movement's artists include Anish Kapoor, Damien Hirst and Eva Hesse.
artists: Joseph Beuys, Chris Burden, Eva Hesse
artworks: "The True Artist Helps the World by Revealing Mystic Truths, (Window or Wall Sign)", "A Line Made by Walking", "Verb List"

description: Post-Painterly Abstraction was a term developed by critic Clement Greenberg in 1964 to describe a diverse range of abstract painters who rejected the gestural styles of the Abstract Expressionists and favored instead what he called "openness or clarity." Painters as different as Ellsworth Kelly and Helen Frankenthaler were described by the term. Some employed geometric form, others veils of stained color.
artists: Morris Louis, Kenneth Noland, Jules Olitski
artworks: "Blue Balls VII", "Dance", "Red Blue"

description: The Pre-Raphaelites were a group of English painters whose goal was to reform art by rejecting the classical influences of Raphael, to return to a more mediaval approach to the arts. Romanticism was a great influence on this group and they were interested honest depictions of nature.
artists: Dante Gabriel Rossetti, John Everett Millais, William Morris
artworks: "The Girlhood of Mary Virgin", "Ecce Ancilla Domini!", "Ophelia"

description: A vast number of major modern artists in the West were greatly influenced by art they deemed 'primitive' or 'naïve', made by tribal or non-Western cultures. Such art, ranging from African, Oriental, Oceanic, and Native American to naive depictions of the French peasantry, was thought to be less civilized and thus closer to raw aesthetic and spiritual experience.
artists: Paul Gaugin, Pablo Picasso, Henri Matisse
artworks: "Vision After the Sermon", "Les Demoiselles d'Avignon", "Bathers in a Room"

description: Purism, an offshoot of Cubism, was a style advocated by architect Le Corbusier and artist Amadee Ozenfant. Frequently abstract, Purist works contain smooth geometric forms, even paint application, and machine-like shapes.
artists: Le Corbusier, Juan Gris, Fernand Léger
artworks: "Still Life", "Bottle and Fruit Bowl", "Nature morte"

description: "Queer Art" became a powerful political and celebratory term to describe the art and experience of gay, lesbian, bisexual, transgender, and intersex people.
artists: Claude Cahun, Francis Bacon, David Hockney
artworks: "Medallion (YouWe)", "Two Figures", "We Two Boys Together Clinging"

description: Rayonism, sometimes refered to as rayism, was an abstract style of painting developed by Russian artists Mikhail Larionov and Natalia Goncharova. The term was derived from the use of dynamic rays of contrasting color that represented lines of reflected light.
artists: Natalia Goncharova, Mikhail Larionov
artworks: "Peacock in Bright Sunlight (Egyptian Style)", "Old-Fashioned Love"

description: Realism is an approach to art that stresses the naturalistic representation of things, the look of objects and figures in ordinary life. It emerged as a distinct movement in the mid-nineteenth century, in opposition to the idealistic, sometimes mythical subjects that were then popular, but it can be traced back to sixteenth-century Dutch art and forward into twentieth-century styles such as Social Realism.
artists: Gustave Courbet, Jean-François Millet, Édouard Manet
artworks: "Rue Transnonain, le 15 Avril 1834", "A Burial at Ornans", "The Stone Breakers"

description: Rococo was a far reaching artistic movement associated with ornate decoration that included architecture, painting, sculpture, music, interior design, landscape design, and theater.
artists: Jean-Antoine Watteau, Canaletto, Tiepolo
artworks: "Pilgrimage to the Isle of Cythera", "Pierrot", "The Entrance to the Grand Canal"

description: Romanticism was a nineteenth-century movement that celebrated the powers of emotion and intuition over rational analysis or classical ideals. Romantic artists emphasized awe, beauty, and the sublime in their works, which frequently charted the darker or chaotic sides of human life.
artists: Henry Fuseli, William Blake, Antoine Jean Gros
artworks: "The Nightmare", "The Ancient of Days from Europe a Prophecy copy B", "Bonaparte Visits the Plague Stricken in Jaffa"

description: After the Russian Revolution, collaborative groups of futurists formed in St. Petersburg and in Moscow, publishing journals, organizing debates, and curating exhibitions of their work. Artists such as Natalya Goncharova, Kasimir Malevich, and Vladimir Mayakovsky reject past approaches and looked to Russian icongraphy, French Cubism, and the avant-garde of Europe for new directions for art-making.
artists: Natalia Goncharova, Velimir Khlebnikov, Aleksei Kruchenykh
artworks: "Haycutters", "Igra v adu", "Dyr bul shchyl"

description: The Salon Cubists built upon the early Cubist experiments of Pablo Picasso and George Braque and painted large scale, vibrant paintings.
artists: Fernand Léger, Robert Delaunay
artworks: "Abundance", "Woman with Phlox", "Woman with a Horse"

description: The School of London was a post-war group of painters who rejected the avant-garde trends of the time and helped reinvigorate figurative art.
artists: Francis Bacon, R. B. Kitaj, Lucian Freud
artworks: "Girl with a White Dog", "Sleeping Figure", "Melanie and Me Swimming"

description: Situationist International was agroup of social revolutionaries who were avant-garde artists, intellectuals, and political theorists that joined to critique capitalism and social issues.
artists: Guy Debord, Asger Jorn, Ralph Rumney
artworks: "Psychogeographique de Paris. Speech on the Passions of Love", "Letter to my Son", "The Change"

description: Social Realism refers to a style of figurative art with social concerns - generally left-wing. Inspired in part by nineteenth-century Realism, it emerged in various forms in the twentieth century. Political radicalism prompted its emergence in 1930s America, while distaste for abstract art encouraged many in Europe to maintain the style into the 1950s.
artists: Ben Shahn, Jacob Lawrence, Raphael Soyer
artworks: "Cover Image for the New Masses", "Aspects of Negro Life: Song of the Towers", "Death (Lynched Figure)"

description: Socialist Realism is a style of realism that rose to prominence around 1917, after the political upheaval in Russia. This style glorified of Communism and its values through the depictions of powerful and just leaders, and hard-working, happy workers.
artists: Yuri Pimenov, Isaak Brodsky
artworks: "Lenin in Smolny", "New Moscow"

description: The Japanese Sosaku-hanga movement transformed cheap prints previously made for the masses into original and creative works of high art.
artists: Kanae Yamamoto, Kōshirō Onchi
artworks: "Fisherman", "Woman on Deck", "Light Time"

description: Straight Photography is a movement centered on depicting a scene in sharp focus and detail as a way to emphasize the photographic medium and distinguish it from painting. Straight Photographers manipulated darkroom techniques to enhance the photograph with higher contrast and rich tonality.
artists: Paul Strand, Diane Arbus, Ansel Adams
artworks: "Bowls", "Monolith, the Face of Half Dome"

description: Street Art encompasses any visual art created in public locations, specifically unsanctioned artwork and graffiti.
artists: Banksy, Keith Haring, Daniel Buren
artworks: "Untitled (Tag on Pole)", "Untitled (New York Subway Graffiti)", "Tango"

description: Street photography captures the moments of everyday life in public places. Photographers rely on framing and timing to immortalize a candid, sometimes called "decisive" moment. Alfred Stieglitz, Henri Cartier-Bresson, Helen Levitt, and Walker Evans were innovators of the movement.
artists: Brassai, Robert Frank, Helen Levitt
artworks: "New York (Children with Broken Mirror)", "Bijoux de Montmartre, Bar de la Lune", "Place de l'Europe"

description: Superflat is a postmodern art movement founded by Takashi Murakami, that is named for the flattened forms found in prevalent and historic Japanese graphic art, animation, pop culture, and fine arts. Superflat uses the juxtaposition of old and new techniques to explore subjects such as consumerism and sexual fetishism.
artists: Takashi Murakami
artworks: "My Lonesome Cowboy", "727", "A to Z Memorial Dog"

description: Suprematism was founded by Russian artist Kazimir Malevich in 1915. Using geometric shapes--as simple as a black square on a white ground or as complex as myriad bars, trapezoids, and circles arranged in space--Suprematism sought to convey the fundamental and transcendent properties of art.
artists: Kazimir Malevich, El Lissitzky
artworks: "Black Square", "Supremist Painting, Eight Red Rectangles"

description: Perhaps the most influential avant-garde movement of the century, Surrealism was founded by a small group of writers and artists who sought to channel the unconscious as a means to unlock the power of the imagination. They hoped that the psyche had the power to reveal the contradictions in the everyday world and spur on revolution.
artists: Hans Arp, Max Ernst, Salvador Dalí
artworks: "Carnival of Harlequin", "The Human Condition", "Mama, Papa is Wounded!"

description: Symbolism is an artistic and literary movement that first emerged in France in the 1880s. In the visual arts it is often considered part of Post-Impressionism. It is characterized by an emphasis on the mystical, romantic and expressive, and often by the use of symbolic figures.
artists: Paul Gaugin, Gustave Moreau, Odilon Redon
artworks: "Jupiter and Semele", "The Eye Like a Strange Balloon Mounts Toward Infinity", "Death and Masks"

description: Synchromism was an American art movement started in the avant-garde explosion in Paris at the beginning of the 20th century. The movement aimed to create color "symphonies" by particular arrangements of shapes and hues. Based on musical principles, the resulting paintings were often abstract and dynamic.
artists: Thomas Hart Benton, Stuart Davis
artworks: "Synchromy in Orange: To Form", "Day of Good Fortune"

description: The Pictures Generation was a loosely knit group of artists working in photography, and video who utilized appropriation and montage to reveal the constructed nature of images.
artists: Cindy Sherman, Jack Goldstein, Sherrie Levine
artworks: "Untitled Film Still #21", "Men in the Cities", "Blasted Allegories(Colorful Sentence): Surly Swoon"

description: The Tonalists aspired to emulate musicality and inspire contemplation. By arranging color and forms, they believed that landscapes could evoke emotion and harmony.
artists: James Whistler, Georgia Inness, Edward Steichen
artworks: "Arrangement in Grey and Black No. 1", "Nocturne in Black and Gold: The Falling Rocket", "Arques-la-Bataille"

description: The major Japanese art movement Ukiyo-e (woodblock prints) often featured images of beautiful women, landscapes, kabuki theater, and scenes from history. They were very influential and inspirational for the Impressionist and later Western modernists.
artists: Hishikawa Moronobu, Suzuki Harunobu, Torri Kiyonaga
artworks: "Two Lovers", "Interior of a Bathhouse"

description: Video art is a medium that employs moving images of various types, but often contains no narrative, characters or discernible storyline. Not to be confused with, for example, the experimental film or cinema, Video art first developed in the 1960s further avant-garde movements such as Performance, Intallation, and Feminist art.
artists: Nam June Paik, Bruce Nauman, Joan Jonas
artworks: "Sleep", "Sun In Your Head - Television Décollage", "TV Cello"

description: The Vienna Secession was a group of Austrian painters, sculptors and architects, who in 1897 resigned from the main Association of Austrian Artists with the mission of bringing modern European art to culturally-insulated Austria. Among the Secession's founding members were Gustav Klimt, Koloman Moser, Josef Hoffmann and Joseph Maria Olbrich.
artists: Gustav Klimt, Charles Rennie Mackintosh
artworks: "Aureol", "Pallas Athene"

description: Viennese Actionism was a violent art movement in the twentieth century that led to the development of action art in the 1960s. Gunter Brus, Otto Muhl, and Hermann Nitsch were among its main participants. The Actionists' work is marked by the use of nudity, destruction, and violence. The artists often used the body as their artistic surface.
artists: VALIE EXPORT, Gunter Brus, Otto Muehl
artworks: "Ana", "Piss Aktion", "Action Number Six: Vienna Walk"

description: Vorticism was a short-lived British avant-garde art movement of the early twentieth century. Led by Wyndham Lewis and Ezra Pound, the group celebrated the energy and dynamism of the modern machine age and declared an assault on staid British traditions.
artists: Wyndham Lewis, Jacob Epstein
artworks: "In the Station of the Metro", "Red Stone Dancer"

description: The Washington Color School refers to a group of painters including Noland, Louis, and Truitt. Their work is marked by the presence of color areas, washes, and geometric designs that emphasized the two-dimensional surface of the picture plane and its lack of reference to any subject matter.
artists: Kenneth Noland, Morris Louis, Anne Truitt
artworks: "Beginning", "Faces", "Insurrection"

description: The Wiener Werkstätte was an early-twentieth-century production company of artists, founded in Vienna in 1903, by architect Josef Hoffmann. It developed largely in response to the Vienna Secession, inspiring others to found a company that catered to artists working in all variety of media, from jewelry and ceramics to metalworks and furniture making. The company was quite successful, opening branches in Karlsbad, Zurich, Berlin and New York.
artists: Josef Hoffmann, Koloman Moser
artworks: "Palais Stoclet", "Wiener Werkstätte letterhead", "Sitzmaschine chair"

description: Yoga art, or Western-style painting was a major Japanese movement made in accordance with European conventions and ideas from the 1870s to the 1950s.
artists: Takahashi Yuichi, Asai Chū
artworks: "Salmon", "Spring Ridge", "A Maiko Girl"

description: Young British Artists is the name given to a group of conceptual artist, painters, sculptors and installation artists based in the United Kingdon, most of whom attended Goldsmiths College in London. The title is derived from shows of that name staged at the Saatchi Gallery from 1992 onwards, which brought the artists to fame.
artists: Damien Hirstm Tracey Emin, Rachel Whiteread
artworks: "The Physical Impossibility of Death In The Mind of Someone Living", "My Bed", "Market"
